titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
May day— I filed once more alphabetically the Letters received since the commencement of the year; to find among them any which might require an answer and yet remain unanswered— I did find several, and among them one upwards of a year old— Several of later date, but still obsolete—and I received Letters from Minott Thayer and Bryant Newcomb of Braintree. Mr Thayer’s Letter informs me that just at the close of the late Session of the Legislature of Massachusetts, he called the members from the 12th. Congressional District together, and they passed Resolutions appointing a Committee to congratulate me upon my return home, and to express their sense of my services at the late Session of Congress. Mr Thayer, as Chairman of the Committee enquires when I may be expected home— I answered him, I hoped not later than the 20th. of this month; and probably not sooner than the 15th.— The Letter from Bryant Newcomb, was in behalf of a widow Spear, having a claim for a Pension— I took it to the Pension-Office, and Mr Edwards promised to examine the Massachusetts records, and see if they furnished proof of the service. He said also that he would report to me to-morrow upon the cases of Huldah Penniman, and of Jerusha Ripley— He should send me the certificate in the case of Mrs Penniman; but in that of Mrs Ripley there was only a Petition stating her claim instead of a Declaration upon Oath, which the Law requires.— We had morning visits from Captain Wadsworth of the U.S. Navy and Mrs. Wadsworth— He has just returned in the frigate Brandywine from the Station in the Pacific— Sailed from Callao in January and arrived after a passage of 94 days at Norfolk— I made some enquiries of him concerning the present condition of Peru— Our public journals take little more notice of the affairs of South-America than of the interior of China— Captain Wadsworth says that Santa-Cruz, formerly President of Upper Peru or Bolivia, was when he left Lima, President of Peru with dictatorial powers. That Bolivia, is now united with Peru; which consists of three divisions—North and South Peru, and Bolivia—that the Government de facto is a military despotism; but that they have a Congress; and continue to be occupied in making Constitutions of which they have had three or four, since he went upon that Station— At his departure they were on the point of War, which has since been declared against Chili—a country much more tranquil, and more prosperous— But in truth there seems to be no cement in these new Independent States, formed out of Spanish Colonies— After the North American Revolution, we had only five or six years of languor, and imbecility, and approximations to civil War— None such occurred between the States, but there was a serious insurrection in Massachusetts— Within seven years from the Preliminary Articles of Peace with Great-Britain, the Constitution of the United States had been constructed and adopted, and was in full operation— The 25th. Congress under that Constitution has commenced; and the close of that Congress will be the Jubile of the Constitution.— One half century has passed over the heads of this People; with scarcely enough internal dissension to create a convulsion— Without Secession of one State from the Union—with only two light insurrections, within the first ten years, rather reasoned down than subdued by force— With short War with Great-Britain
Great-Britain and a Quasi-war with France— In that time, the number of the States has doubled; the population more than quadrupled— The extent of Territory more than doubled— The wealth more than ten-fold, and Justice the great object for which Governments are instituted among men has been administered however imperfectly, with more approach to perfection than in any other Country upon Earth— This is an excellent subject for that discourse which I have conditionally promised to deliver before the American Historical Society of Military and Naval Events, at New-York next November; and about which I ought very soon to set to work— Wilson was here this morning—he has made his engagement with the French Minister— I walked this afternoon round the Capitol— Evening hour at Cards.

I went at ten this morning with Elizabeth C. Adams, and the two children Louisa and Fanny to the Columbian College, and attended an exhibition of the Senior and junior Classes— The College was some years since broken up, and since it was resumed has continually languished— There are only four Students in the Senior Class, of whom T. B. J. Frye is one— In the Junior class there are 11. and there were 15 parts to be performed—four of them were excused— The rest occupied about ten minutes each, with a beginning close and three intervals of instrumental music.— The performers were all in English prose, and generally below the average of such exhibitions at other colleges—almost every one of the performers was grossly deficient in Memory; but the elocution was generally good— The best piece was a dissertation upon the Poetry of the Hebrews by a Virginian named Herndon, and pilfered from Hazlett or Campbell— The President Dr Chapin was absent and Professor Ruggles presided—the Mayor of the City Mr Force was there; and Mrs Catherine Brown; one of the performers J. D. Kurtz being I believe her Grandson— I was requested by the faculty to enter the Chapel and take a seat on the stage with them— The exhibition was over about 1. O’Clock and I took my companions with me into the race grounds, where we saw two three Mile heats run, and taken by the same horse— I had not been at a race before these ten years or more— Dr Huntt was there on the stand among the judges; though the weather was excessively chilling. There was to be another race, but we did not wait for it. Thomas Frye rode home with us.— I found on my table Letters from J. L. Edwards Commissioner of Pensions, with Pension certificates—for Mrs Mary Partridge sometime widow of Ichabod Alden, and for Huldah Penniman, sometime widow of Barnabas Hollis, and now of Bethuel Penniman: and rejecting for insufficient evidence the claims of Jerusha Ripley, and Elizabh. Spear. I wrote immediately to Mrs Partridge, and to Samuel Alden Frazar who had requested me to enquire into her claim— The certificate entitles her to the receipt of 3600 dollars immediately and to a pension of 600 dollars a year for the rest of her life— I then went and dined with Mr W. W. Seaton; where besides Mrs Seaton, her daughter and niece, I met her father Mr Joseph Gales Senior, Dr Follen and Mr Pishey Thompson— Had a very pleasant dinner, with the only dissatisfaction that I engrossed far too great a part of the conversation— Dr Follen told me that he had examined the Bible with reference to the remarks that I made to him the other day, upon the Covenants between God and Man—and
and had found them surprizingly numerous— I urged him to take up the subject and carry it out into all its consequences, and see if it would not lead him to the conclusion that the power to make a covenant or promise is a part and a proof of the immortality of man’s nature— At half past seven Dr Follen delivered at the Unitarian Church the last of his course of Lectures, which I attended, and it contained a recapitulation of the whole course— His text was from John 16.12. [“]I have yet many things to say unto you, but ye cannot hear them now— 13. Howbeit when he, the Spirit of truth, is come, he will guide you into all truth”—omitting the remainder of the verse.— And he read the 20th. chapter of Acts from verse 16 to the end of the chapter,—Paul’s valedictory at Ephesus— And this also was a very affectionate taking of leave— Dr. Follen pronounces the English, almost like a native, and speaks it grammatically without elegance. His style is clear and perspicuous, and the turn of his mind argumentative and logical. When I returned home, I found Mrs Thornton, Mrs Talbot her Son and Daughter, Mr and Mrs Frye with their Son and daughter, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith here; where they had passed the Evening— Soon after I came in, they retired— Mr Smith returned on Sunday evening from New-York.

As old age steals upon me, I feel more and more the want of tranquility, and the annoyance of agitation— Yesterday was a whole day of bustle and commotion— It continued till near Midnight, and after all I had not a quiet Night— Awoke this morning before the dawn, and rose by five O’Clock when there was scarcely daylight to dress by— Mr Whitcomb was here and informed me that he had accepted an Office as a Clerk with a Salary of 800 dollars a year under the second Comptroller of the Treasury, Albion K. Parris, sometime Governor of the State of Maine— He came to make enquiries whether it would be advisable for him to make application for the admission of his Son now 13 years of age as a Cadet at the West Point Academy. I told him I could not advise him against making the application; because I saw not that it could do any harm; but a new or revised system of Regulations had been adopted at the War Department, a printed copy of which he could easily procure— By this system one Cadet was allotted to each congressional District throughout the United States and the member of the House of Representatives from the same District was called upon to make the nomination— I had accordingly within a few weeks been notified, by the Chief Engineer, General Gratiot, that there was at the Academy a vacancy for the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts to fill which I was authorised to make a nomination; and had accordingly made one for a youth named Tower, who had accordingly received the warrant— But the regulations expressly gave notice, that priority of application would give no priority of claim when the appointments should be made; and upon my being requested to file in the Department a recommendation of a youth from Boston, in the District adjoining upon mine, General Gratiot had told me, that it could
could be of no use, as when the vacancy should occur the nomination must be made by the member from the District— Mr Whitcomb was sometime a subordinate Officer in the custom-house at Boston; but residing at Dorchester— He lately resigned that station, and removed to the State of Vermont, and has now taken the place here, in the expectation of a better office hereafter—for which he feels himself to be fully competent— I wrote Letters to Jonathan Parker at Plympton, respecting the claim to a widows Pension, of Mrs Jerusha Ripley—to Bryant Newcomb at Braintree, in answer to his enquiries in behalf of Mrs Elizabeth Spear; and to Reuben Baldwin of Boston to enclose the Pension certificate for Mrs Huldah Pennyman. Called at the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions, and took back the Letter from Reuben Baldwin to me, which had enclosed the Petition of Huldah Pennyman; and also the affidavit of Zebedee Cushman; one of the vouchers to the Petition of Jerusha Ripley, which Mr Edwards had omitted accidentally to include with those he sent me yesterday— I found upon enquiry from him that the vouchers for the claim of Mrs Mary Partridge, had been received by him on the 23d. of March last from Mr Jacob H Loud of Plymouth— I was walking for a tour round the Capitol when a distant thunder-clap, and a sprinkling of rain warned me to turn back and fetch home—immediately after which there was a heavy thunder shower. After dinner I took a second walk— Evening Cards—and nothing from Horace.

I wrote this morning to Mr Jacob H. Loud of Plymouth, and thus squared off my correspondence, respecting the claims for Pensions, in behalf of which I had received Letters during the late Session of Congress— I have now nothing to detain me here longer than the time necessary to make preparations for departure— But not having heard from the Secretary of the Treasury, concerning the Letter from Mr William Ellis that I had left with him some weeks since, I called at his Office to enquire about it— He had referred it to the first Auditor, the acting Officer in which had addressed to me on the 24th. of last Month a Letter, which I had not received, in answer to Mr Ellis’s enquiries— The Letter it seems had been addressed to me at Baltimore; the Newspapers having announced my visit there, and not my return— The Letter was read to me from the Book, and a copy of it was sent to me in the course of the day: with the printed Report, made by Caleb Cushing, from the Committee of Foreign Relations, on the 1st. of March last on the petition of William C. Parke, which was not acted upon by the House. Parke is the Son of the Captain of Marines Parke of the Frigate Alliance— On my walk round the Capitol I called twice at the Office of the Franklin Insurance Company, but there was no one there— Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here with Mrs Adams— I went to the May-Ball given by the French dancing master Monsieur L’Abbé, to exhibit his pupils. Mary and Elizabeth went also, with Robert M. Buchanan, who returned this afternoon from his visit to Annapolis— It was at Carusi’s Salloon— The number of pupils, boys and girls is near one hundred children from five or six to twenty years old— The exhibition was lively and pleasant, and Mary’s two children, were among the most distinguished of the little dancers— The Queen of
of May, was a daughter of Major Wainwright, about 15 years of age. The Hall was crowded with company, not many of whom were known to me The Secretary of the Treasury Woodbury and his family were there, and I had some conversation with him— Also with C. B. King the Painter and with Mr Agg, who urged me with no small importunity to write a History of the United States, or of my own Times.— I fear I have lost and am losing the time to accomplish this— While I remain in Congress more than half the year is totally absorbed in performing the duties of my Station—and while at Quincy, my mode of life occasions of an enormous waste of time— If I cannot change it, the possibility of completing even a tolerable Memoir of my father’s life will be lost— We came home about 11. O’Clock, and Robert Buchanan and Thomas Frye came with us to pass the night here— I met this morning Mr Heman Lincoln of Massachusetts also is transiently in the City— He told me that Arthur Tappan of New-York had failed— For the last two Months there have been a succession of enormous failures in New-Orleans and New-York, extending to Philadelphia, Boston, and partially to other cities— The blowing up has been the most extensive in New-York—where after various other abortive expedients a great whig meeting was held and a Committee of fifty persons appointed to come to Washington to remonstrate with him against the Administration— And to demand 1. that he should rescind the Treasury circular forbidding the Western Land-Offices to receive any thing but gold and silver in payment for the Public Lands 2. That he would order a suspension of the collection of the custom-house bonds, till next January 3. that he would convoke Congress at an early day. A sub-committee of fifteen members are said to have been here yesterday and this day. At their first interview with President Van Buren, he required that whatever proposition they had to offer should be made in writing— This was accordingly done, and the general rumour is that the answer was negative upon all the demands.

A leap from January to July— This was one of the hottest days of the year; and being the day following on Evening of dissipation, melted itself also nearly into nothing— Robert Buchanan and Thomas Frye left us after Breakfast— I wrote to Mr William Ellis at Dedham, and enclosed to him the Report of the acting first Auditor, on his Letter, and Mr Cushing’s printed Report from the Committee of Foreign Relations, on the Petition of Captain Parke’s Son— I undertook also to answer the Letter from John Herkimer received last January with an enclosed Letter from H. Gros to him concerning certain papers said to have been delivered to me by Mr Herkimer, when I was Secretary of State— Mr Dayton Chief Clerk of the Department of State informs me that after strict examination no trace of the Papers or of any thing relating to them can be found either upon the files or the Records of the Department. This I communicated to Mr Herkimer; but the Letter from Gros to him refers to a letter which he says he wrote to me when I was President making enquiries, about
the Papers, and which remained unanswered— I now examined my files of Letters received when I was President; and after emptying and overhauling nearly one whole chest full, I found the Letter from H. Gros, endorsed by my Son John “with out date; received 2. Feby 1826.” and pencil-marked by me D. B. meaning Daniel Brent, to whom it was doubtless referred at the time to make the examination at the Department. This Letter names the Winter of 1824 as the time when Mr Herkimer put the papers into my hands— I suspended the conclusion of my answer to Mr Herkimer, and took Gros’s new discovered Letter, together with the other two, to the Department of State, where I saw Mr Forsyth the Secretary, and left the three Letters with him requesting a further examination of the files and records; and particularly of the Instructions to James Brown who was the Minister in France, in 1824. and to Daniel Sheldon, who was about that time the Chargé d’Affaires—both since dead— Mr Forsyth told me that since the expiration of our Treaty of 1822. limited to ten years duration, and adjusting the respective pretensions of the two Countries on the Northwest Coast of America, one of our merchant vessels has again been warned off from a Russian Settlement, and the Russian pretensions in that sea have all been revived— He said he had been intending to visit me at my house to have a conversation with me on the subject— He shewed me the Article of the Treaty which settled the controversy for the time, and the despatch from Mr Middleton with the Protocol of his Conferences with the Russian Plenipotentiaries Nesselrode and Poletica— Mr Forsyth seems to apprehend that there was some concession on the part of Mr Middleton, of which the Russian Government might now take some advantage; but I saw no occasion for such apprehension. The Article of the Treaty having expired, remitted each of the parties to their respective rights, and pretensions; and the Emperor Alexander having fully indemnified after the conclusion, of the Treaty, the owners of the vessel which had been turned away by virtue of his hundred league ukase, had made the effective concession, if there was one to be imputed to either party— I walked to the Office of the Franklin Insurance Company—and received the half-yearly dividend which was now ten per Cent—reserving still 6 2/3 per Cent for the next dividend— But Mr Bradley told me that the new Company at Georgetown would take from the Franklin company one third part of their profits.— Walking home I was almost suffocated with heat as oppressive as that of the dog-days— Mr and Mrs Poinsett paid us an Evening visit and I abandoned the Evening to idleness.

I had a Letter this morning from my Son, and concluded to take the chance of going home alone next week, leaving my family to follow me, if it may be after the first of next Month— To assist in effecting which I wrote short Letters to Dr James Laurie, and to Mr George Wood the Treasurer of the Columbian College which I left at their respective Offices.— Before leaving the City I thought it a decent mark of courtesy to visit Mr Van Buren at the President’s house— I went accordingly, and was received by him in his Cabinet, alone. I had
I had not before set my foot, in the house since I left it on the evening of the 3d. of March 1829— The conversation with Mr Van Buren was upon subjects of a general nature, and not at-all upon the public affairs of the Country— Upon the inconvenience of a Summer residence in this City, and on my custom heretofore when under that necessity of bathing and swimming every morning in the Potowmack— Then upon the general state of European Politics— He spoke of unfriendly relations existing between Great-Britain and Russia, and between Russia and Prussia— Of the character of the Crown Prince of Prussia, as violent, and of his reputation as unpopular— Of dissensions between the present king of England, William the 4th. and the Duchess of Kent, mother of the Princess Victoria, presumptive heiress to the Crown, and coming of age on the 24th. of this Month— I mentioned my intention to leave the City next Tuesday, and he asked me to remember him respectfully to my Son; and his wife— After a call at the Bank of the Metropolis I went to the Patent Office, to make enquiries concerning a Patent, for Ira L. Beckwith of Quincy, mentioned in my Son’s Letter, received this morning— The Commissioner of Patents Henry L. Ellsworth was not at the Office, but Mr Hand, a clerk in the Office informed me that the Patent had been despatched to Mr Beckwith on the 29th. of April. I went to the Capitol, and returned to the Library of Congress all the books that I had taken out— The Librarian John S. Meehan was absent, having been for some weeks confined by indisposition I enquired of the Assistant Librarian Edward B. Stelle, whether a Letter had been received by the Librarian from Mr Persico immediately before his departure, respecting the disposal of my bust executed by him which is yet there— He had no knowledge of such Letter, but said he would enquire of the Librarian, and if there was such, he would send me a copy of it— At the door of the Office of the House of Representatives I met Mr Leonard Jarvis, who told me that he was going this afternoon for home, and of whom I took a parting and perhaps final leave— I had met him yesterday in the entry of the Department of State, with Mr Joseph Hall, also a member of the late Congress from Maine, and who he says is now here upon some Post-Office contract— In the Clerk’s Office I obtained the printed sheets of the Journals of the late House of Representatives from the 14th. of February to the 2d. of March, and 4 copies of the document containing the correspondence of William Tudor junr. while he was Consul at Lima, and political agent in Peru— Mr Burch is still confined to his house, but expected to be out again next Monday. They promised to send me the remaining sheets of the Journal of the House when printed. My next call was on Mr Fendall, to whom I returned the two Volumes of the Federalist belonging to the Washington City Library, which he had borrowed for me, and which have the initials of the names of the respective authors of each number in Mr Madison’s hand-writing; being the copy from which Gideon’s Edition of 1819. was printed— On my return home I stopped at Mr Cutts’s house, and took up the two children, who had spent the morning there, and brought them home. A Northwestern gale this afternoon, again swept the sky and chilled the atmosphere, raising clouds of dust, which deterred me from the Postmeridian walk— Evening cards.

I attended Church morning and afternoon at St. John’s Church and heard Mr Hawley read the services for the Sunday after Ascension day— His morning Sermon was from Matthew 8.26—latter part of the verse— [“]Then he arose, and rebuked the winds and the sea; and there was a great calm.” That of the afternoon was from Isaiah 11.9. “They shall not hurt nor destroy, in all my holy mountain: for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the Lord, as the waters cover the sea.” There is so little point in the connection between Mr Hawley’s texts and his Sermons, that either of these texts might with equal propriety have been placed at the head of either of the discourses— Mr Hawley is a man of excellent Character, and adapted to preach the Gospel more effectively by his life than by his eloquence. He gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday being Whitsunday or the day of Pentecost— Robert M. Buchanan dined with us— Mrs Frye, and her Son Thomas were here in the afternoon; and Mrs W. S. Smith; and Mr Frye spent the Evening with me— He communicated to me the state of Affairs in my hands—a subject of as little amusement as of profit— He spoke of leasing and repairing houses; of the Columbia flour Mills, and explained how these Mills the building of which cost 50000 dollars, were now of no value as flour Mills whatever. The main cause is the Baltimore Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, which has diverted the course of trade in wheat to Baltimore— There is now no market for wheat at Georgetown— Mr Frye advised to turn the Mills themselves to some other account, for example for paper making—but there is no such good fortune for me— Mr Frye proposed also repairs to the amount of 200 dollars upon the house near J. P. Van Ness’s, and said enquiry had been made of him what I would take for the house which I bought of Daniel Baker— I authorised him to offer it for 1500 dollars cash. and if that did not suit to ask for an offer— I gave him the account I had drawn up in Novr. 1834, against Mrs Doyne which he thought he could recover— He said he had a balance of upwards of 100 dollars of mine in his hand, which I requested him to pay over to my wife as she might want it— Mrs Tudor had repeatedly sent to request me to call on her before my departure for home, which I did this morning after the service— I took with me a copy of the document of her Son William’s correspondence while he was consul General at Lima, and political agent of this Government in Peru. It forms a pamphlet of upwards of 200 pages, and one of the most interesting diplomatic correspondences which has ever taken place under the Government of the United States— I returned to her also the small account Book, which Mrs Stewart had requested me to take, and containing charges for travelling expences, which she thought should be claimed; but which Mr Pleasonton the 5th. Auditor was not disposed to allow— Mrs Stewart was much indisposed with an intermittent fever.

I received this morning 2 Letters of the 3d. and 4th. from my Son; the latter containing a seasonable remittance of 500 dollars, which enables me to pay a very small portion of my debts here. He sent me also a Letter from a Committee of Arrangements chosen at a Meeting of the Inhabitants of Newbury Port; for celebrating the next anniversary of Independence, Samuel T. Delord, Edward Burrill Thomas Davis and John Bradbury—inviting me to deliver an Oration there on that day— This is the most perplexing application that I have received for a public performance of that kind; and I know not how to answer it— I received also a note from the Secretary of State, returning me, the Letters from John Herkimer, and H. Gros, which I had left at the Department; and informing me that no trace of the papers enquired after by those Letters can be found in the Archives— I wrote to Mr Herkimer to let him know the ill success of my researches— I then called first at the Bank of the Metropolis, where I receiveed my book balanced.
